questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever, malaise, and chest pain. She describes the pain as 6 out of 10 in intensity and that it is more severe if she takes a deep breath. The pain is centrally located in the chest and does not radiate. She had a sore throat 3 weeks ago that resolved without treatment. She has no personal history of serious illness. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F). Examination shows pale conjunctivae. There are several subcutaneous nodules on the elbows and wrist bilaterally. Lungs are clear to auscultation. A soft early systolic murmur is heard best at the apex in the left lateral position. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.6 g/dL


Leukocyte count
12,300/mm3



Platelet count
230,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
40 mm/h


Serum



 Antistreptolysin O titer


327 U/mL (N < 200)


She is treated with aspirin and penicillin and her symptoms resolve. Echocardiography performed 14 days later shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?

choices.text: Intramuscular benzathine penicillin every 4 weeks for 10 years
Low-dose prednisone therapy for a month
Oral penicillin V before dental procedures
Intramuscular benzathine penicillin every 4 weeks until the age of 40
Intramuscular benzathine penicillin every 4 weeks for 5 years

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Intramuscular benzathine penicillin every 4 weeks for 10 years (or until 21 years of age, whichever is longer) is recommended for secondary prophylaxis of recurrent acute rheumatic fever in patients with manifestations of carditis but no permanent valvular damage. Patients and their families should be educated on early recognition of symptoms of ARF and the importance of adhering to prophylaxis.

B) INCORRECT:

Low-dose prednisone therapy is indicated for the symptomatic management of acute rheumatic fever in patients who do not tolerate other anti-inflammatory drugs such as aspirin. However, the patient tolerated aspirin well and her symptoms have since resolved.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic prophylaxis (e.g., oral penicillin V) before dental procedures used to be recommended for patients at moderate risk of infective endocarditis, including those with acute rheumatic fever who had a murmur. However, current guidelines do not recommend this strategy due to a lack of supporting evidence. Instead, antibiotic prophylaxis before dental procedures is now recommended only in patients with prosthetic heart valves, a prior history of infective endocarditis, or certain congenital heart diseases.

D) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular benzathine penicillin every 4 weeks until 40 years of age is recommended for secondary prophylaxis of recurrent acute rheumatic fever for patients with manifestations of carditis and permanent valvular disease. However, residual disease in this patient was ruled out through echocardiography.

E) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular benzathine penicillin every 4 weeks for 5 years (or until 21 years of age, whichever is longer) is recommended for secondary prophylaxis of recurrent acute rheumatic fever in patients without carditis. However, this patient has chest pain and an audible murmur, which indicate carditis.
questions.hint: The patient's presentation with subcutaneous nodules and signs of carditis (chest pain, new-onset heart murmur indicating acute mitral regurgitation) fulfills two of the major revised Jones criteria for acute rheumatic fever (ARF). Additionally, two minor criteria (fever and elevated ESR) are also fulfilled. There is no evidence of permanent valvular damage on echocardiography.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of fever, malaise, and severe right knee joint pain and swelling for 3 days. Five days ago, he had swelling and pain in his left ankle joint which has since resolved. He reports having a sore throat 3 weeks ago while he was camping in the woods, for which he received symptomatic treatment. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 119/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination shows a swollen, tender right knee; range of motion is limited. There are painless 3 to 4-mm nodules over the elbow. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.3 g/dL, leukocyte count is 11,800/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 63 mm/h. Arthrocentesis of the right knee joint yields clear, straw-colored fluid. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows a leukocyte count of 1350/mm3 with 17% neutrophils; no organisms are identified on Gram stain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is a delayed inflammatory complication that occurs 1–5 weeks following an untreated group A beta-hemolytic streptococcal infection, particularly pharyngitis. To diagnose ARF, two major or one major plus two minor revised Jones criteria are required. Major criteria include arthritis (migratory polyarthritis primarily involving the large joints), subcutaneous nodules, carditis (pancarditis, including valvulitis), Sydenham chorea (CNS involvement), and erythema marginatum. Minor criteria include polyarthralgia, fever, elevated acute phase reactants (ESR, CRP), and a prolonged PR interval on ECG. This patient meets 2 major and 3 minor criteria, which is sufficient to establish the diagnosis of ARF.

B) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis occurs most often in patients with prosthetic joint implants and underlying diseases (e.g., immunosuppression, diabetes mellitus), as well as following joint interventions (e.g., surgery, intraarticular injections). Although septic arthritis could explain this patient's pain, erythema, swelling, and a restricted range of motion, the condition is usually limited to a single joint. Synovial fluid analysis would also typically show yellow or green fluid with > 50,000 WBC/μl and ≥ 75% polymorphonuclear leukocytes, as well as low glucose levels and a positive culture.

C) INCORRECT:

Infective endocarditis (IE) could explain this patient's constitutional symptoms of fever, malaise, arthralgia, and elevated ESR, but cardiac manifestations (e.g., a new heart murmur, signs of progressive heart failure) and other extracardiac manifestations (e.g., splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions) would also be expected. Bacterial arthritis due to IE is rare but can occur as a result of bacteremia. However, synovial fluid analysis usually shows yellow or green fluid with > 50,000 WBC/μl and ≥ 75% polymorphonuclear leukocytes, as well as low glucose levels and a positive culture.

D) INCORRECT:

The second stage of Lyme disease (3–10 weeks after infection with Borrelia burgdorferi via tick bite) is characterized by migratory arthralgia and arthritis, as in this patient. However, further findings such as neurologic symptoms (e.g., facial nerve palsy) and cardiac arrhythmias are often present that are not seen in this patient. Additionally, in contrast to the synovial fluid analysis in this vignette, joint aspiration usually shows yellow and cloudy fluid and a leukocyte count that is often highly elevated with > 50% polymorphonuclear leukocytes. This patient's recent camping trip puts him at an increased risk for Lyme disease. Many patients with Lyme disease do not recall a tick bite and, even though ∼ 80% of the infected individuals develop erythema migrans around the bite, the rash is often not noticed if it affects the scalp or the back of the patient. Therefore, if Lyme disease is suspected, serologic testing should be performed even if the patient does not recall a tick bite or initial symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease is an acute vasculitis that most commonly affects children under the age of 5 years, making it an unlikely diagnosis in a 14-year-old boy. Kawasaki disease also causes fever, but diagnosis requires the presence of other findings, such as erythema and edema of the hands and feet, a polymorphous rash, conjunctivitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, and oropharyngeal mucositis (cracked red lips and a strawberry tongue), which are not present in this case.

F) INCORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) manifests before the age of 16 years with arthritis in ≥ 1 joint for ≥ 6 weeks and is associated with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise), extraarticular manifestations (e.g., rheumatoid nodules on the elbows), and an elevated ESR. Synovial fluid analysis is not routinely performed but the results are usually similar to those reported in this case. However, this patient's symptoms have only persisted for 5 days and his recent episode of untreated pharyngitis makes a different diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: Migratory polyarthritis, subcutaneous nodules, and fever following an upper respiratory tract infection are suggestive of an immune-mediated sequela of an infectious disease.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of progressively worsening shortness of breath for 3 days. He has had fever and malaise for the past 5 days. He had a sore throat 3 weeks ago that resolved without treatment. He appears ill. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 98/min and blood pressure is 84/62 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Examination shows jugular venous distension and bilateral ankle edema. There are erythematous, ring-shaped macules and patches over his trunk that are well-demarcated. Auscultation of the chest shows crackles at the lung bases bilaterally. An S3 gallop is heard. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.2 g/dL, leukocyte count is 13,600/mm3, and platelet count is 280,000/mm3. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows cardiac silhouette enlargement with prominent vascular markings in both lung fields. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms (dyspnea, jugular venous distension, bilateral ankle edema, S3 gallop) and chest x-ray findings (enlarged cardiac silhouette, prominent vascular markings) suggest acute heart failure most likely due to carditis. His well-demarcated, erythematous, ring-shaped macules and patches are consistent with erythema marginatum. In the context of his recently untreated sore throat (most likely due to a group A streptococcal infection), the presence of carditis and erythema marginatum (two of the major revised Jones criteria) is consistent with acute rheumatic fever.

B) INCORRECT:

Viral myocarditis can also manifest with symptoms of heart failure. While this patient has jugular venous distention, ankle edema, and x-ray findings consistent with heart failure, his rash (erythema marginatum) suggests an alternative etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Rash is one of the most common presenting symptoms of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which can also affect all layers of the heart (pancarditis). However, the rash seen in SLE is typically a malar rash or discoid rash, as opposed to the rash in this patient, which is suggestive of erythema marginatum. Other common features of SLE which are not present in this patient include arthritis, arthralgia, and/or fatigue.

D) INCORRECT:

Lyme disease can manifest with a ring-like rash with central clearing (erythema migrans) and can also cause carditis. However, Lyme carditis typically manifests as a new cardiac arrhythmia (AV block, sudden death) and rarely as congestive heart failure due to pericarditis. Furthermore, Lyme carditis is a late manifestation of disseminated disease and unlikely to occur simultaneously with the rash.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has had a fever for the past 5 days, which is a key diagnostic feature of Kawasaki disease. Although myocarditis is a known complication of Kawasaki disease and can manifest with signs of congestive heart failure, this patient lacks other salient symptoms of Kawasaki disease such as mucositis, lymphadenopathy, and conjunctivitis. Furthermore, his skin rash is not desquamative but is rather suggestive of erythema marginatum.
questions.hint: Other common sequelae of this patient's condition include arthritis, subcutaneous nodules, and chorea.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 2-day history of high fever and swelling of the left ankle and knee. She had a sore throat 3 weeks ago. There is no family history of serious illness. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She developed an episode of breathlessness and generalized rash when she received dicloxacillin for a skin infection 2 years ago. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38.8°C (102.3°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 98/62 mm Hg. Examination shows swelling and tenderness of the left ankle and knee; range of motion is limited. Lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best at the apex. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin may be administered to treat serious infections with gram-positive pathogens (e.g., MRSA). The patient's joint pain and swelling may suggest septic arthritis, which is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. However, septic arthritis is usually monoarticular. This patient's presentation is consistent with ARF, which is most commonly caused by group A streptococcal (GAS) infection. Vancomycin is not typically used for GAS eradication.

B) CORRECT:

Macrolides such as clarithromycin are the antibiotics of choice for ARF in patients with hypersensitivity to beta-lactam antibiotics. In addition to group A streptococcal eradication therapy, patients with ARF also require symptomatic treatment with NSAIDs for arthritis and fever.

Additionally, an echocardiogram should be performed to evaluate for the presence of rheumatic valvulitis. This patient's apical holosystolic murmur is consistent with mitral regurgitation (likely due to rheumatic valvulitis).

C) INCORRECT:

Low-dose glucocorticoids (not high-dose) may be used for the management of pain and fever in ARF if NSAIDs fail. As this patient is only 12 years old and is febrile, ibuprofen or naproxen should be first administered (aspirin is contraindicated due to the risk of Reye syndrome) instead.

D) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin is a good alternative to penicillin V (the drug of choice) for ARF in children because the taste in oral suspension is better tolerated. However, amoxicillin is contraindicated in this case because the patient has a history of a hypersensitivity reaction to dicloxacillin, which belongs to the same class of drugs (penicillins).

E) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline, a tetracycline, is indicated for the treatment of Lyme disease. Although polyarthritis and cardiac involvement could be suggestive of Lyme disease, this diagnosis is unlikely because the patient has no history of erythema migrans, tick bites, or outdoor stay in a Lyme-endemic region. This patient's presentation is consistent with ARF, which is most commonly caused by group A streptococcal (GAS) infection. GAS has developed widespread resistance to tetracyclines, which renders them ineffective for the treatment of ARF.

F) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate, an antimetabolite, may be administered to treat rheumatologic diseases, such as juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), which is consistent with this patient's polyarthritis. However, she does not have any extraarticular manifestations (e.g., uveitis, rashes, nail changes, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly), making JIA an unlikely diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone, is not typically used in the treatment of ARF, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient. More importantly, fluoroquinolones are contraindicated in children because they may damage developing cartilage and bones.
questions.hint: This patient had a recent sore throat (presumably due to a group A streptococcal infection) and now presents with valvulitis and polyarthritis (two of the major revised Jones criteria), the combination of which is consistent with acute rheumatic fever (ARF). This patient's hypersensitivity to penicillins should be taken into consideration when choosing the appropriate pharmacotherapy.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of abnormal movements of her limbs for 4 days. She has had involuntary nonrhythmic movements of her arms and legs, and has been dropping drinking cups and toys. The symptoms are worse when she is agitated, and she rarely experiences them while sleeping. During this period, she has become increasingly irritable and has had episodes of inappropriate crying. She had a sore throat 5 weeks ago. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 104/64 mm Hg. Examination shows occasional grimacing with abrupt purposeless movements of her limbs. Muscle strength and muscle tone are decreased in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. She has a wide-based and unsteady gait. When the patient holds her arms in extension, flexion of the wrists and extension of the metacarpophalangeal joints occurs. When she squeezes the physician's index and middle fingers with her hands, her grip increases and decreases continuously. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A cerebral viral infection, such as viral encephalitis, can manifest with behavioral changes and abnormal movements, which are seen in this patient. However, cerebral viral infections cause fever and altered mental status, which are not seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Although a tumor in the posterior fossa (e.g., a cerebellar tumor) may cause some of the findings seen in this patient (e.g., behavioral changes, ataxia, and abnormal movements), symptom onset is typically insidious. This patient's rapid onset of symptoms is not consistent with a cerebellar tumor.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's Sydenham chorea is most likely secondary to Group A streptococcal (GAS) infection. Antibodies produced in response to streptococcal M protein can cross-react with proteins of certain tissues (e.g., myocardial, nerve, joint) because of molecular mimicry. This cross-reactivity triggers a type II hypersensitivity reaction that causes local inflammation, which manifests as acute rheumatic fever (ARF). Sydenham chorea, which is caused by inflammation within the basal ganglia and cortical structures, can occur months after the initial infection and is the only manifestation of ARF in up to 30% of affected individuals. Treatment with penicillin V is indicated to completely eradicate GAS infection and address the underlying cause of the antibody cross-reaction. Patients may also require corticosteroid treatment and/or antipsychotic therapy (for severe symptoms). Recovery typically occurs within 6 months.

In patients with chorea and a history of sore throat, a presumptive clinical diagnosis of ARF can be made. Testing for GAS infection is indicated in these patients, but because there is a long latent period, evidence of infection is not always found. Echocardiography should be obtained in all patients with Sydenham chorea because concomitant rheumatic heart disease is common.

D) INCORRECT:

A trinucleotide repeat mutation is the underlying cause of both Huntington disease (HD) and myotonic dystrophy (MD). HD usually becomes symptomatic around 40 years of age but may begin in childhood (juvenile HD). Juvenile HD manifests with behavioral changes and abnormal movements, but this patient's rapid onset of symptoms along with the absence of family history and hyperreflexia make this diagnosis unlikely. Although MD commonly manifests in childhood with muscle weakness, this symptom is caused by muscle atrophy, which is not seen in this patient. Additionally, the most prominent feature of MD is delayed muscle relaxation after normal contraction rather than the inability to sustain contraction. Finally, patients with MD usually have myopathic facial features, such as a long, narrow face, high-arched palate, and ptosis.

E) INCORRECT:

An autosomal recessive genetic mutation is the underlying cause of ataxia-telangiectasia. Although ataxia-telangiectasia can manifest with abnormal movements and ataxia, which are seen in this patient, it also causes cutaneous and ocular telangiectasia and abnormal eye movements, which this patient does not have. Moreover, in contrast to this scenario, ataxia-telangiectasia does not usually have an acute onset, and patients tend to have a history of chronic sinopulmonary infections.
questions.hint: In a child with a recent history of sore throat, rapid onset of involuntary purposeless movements, emotional lability, hypotonia, inability to sustain contraction (milkmaid grip), and flexion of the wrist and extension of the digits when the arms are extended (choreic hand) most likely indicate Sydenham chorea.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the physician for a 6-month history of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. He immigrated to the United States 35 years ago from India. His pulse is 89/min and blood pressure is 145/60 mm Hg. Crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur loudest at the left sternal border in the third intercostal space. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is seen in patients with aortic stenosis, which can present with angina, syncope, and heart failure. Aortic stenosis is characterized by a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur, unlike the diastolic murmur heard in this patient. Pulsus parvus et tardus is not a typical feature of aortic regurgitation.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulsus paradoxus is characterized by decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration and is classically seen in patients with cardiac tamponade and/or constrictive pericarditis. Pulsus paradoxus is not a feature of aortic regurgitation.

C) INCORRECT:

Fixed splitting of S2 most commonly occurs as a result of pathologic processes that increase right ventricular volume (thereby delaying pulmonic valve closure), such as an atrial septal defect. Fixed splitting of S2 is not characteristic of aortic regurgitation.

D) CORRECT:

A water hammer pulse is a classic finding on cardiovascular examination in patients with significant aortic regurgitation, and results from the rapid ejection of a large stroke volume into a low-pressure arterial system. Other findings in patients with aortic regurgitation may include pulse-synchronous head nodding (de Musset sign) and Austin Flint murmur.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical splitting of S2 refers to the pathological closure of the pulmonary valve before the aortic valve, resulting in an S2 split with expiration (instead of the physiologic splitting of S2 heard normally with inspiration). Paradoxical splitting is caused by conditions that delay left ventricular outflow, such as aortic stenosis or left bundle branch block. It is not typically heard in aortic regurgitation.
Image Description:

P2 precedes A2 (audible during expiration but not inspiration).

Certain conditions (e.g., aortic stenosis, left bundle branch block) delay the closure of the aortic valve, resulting in P2 preceding A2. In inspiration, P2 is also delayed (physiological), causing a paradoxical decrease in the split.

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of left heart failure, a high pulse pressure, and an early diastolic murmur at Erb's point (left sternal border, third intercostal space), which suggests chronic aortic regurgitation. Based on his history of emigration from India, this patient likely has rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of aortic regurgitation in resource-limited countries.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-week history of malaise and chest pain. Three weeks ago, she had a sore throat that resolved without treatment. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F). Examination shows several subcutaneous nodules on her elbows and wrist bilaterally and a new-onset early systolic murmur best heard at the apex in the left lateral position. An endomysial biopsy is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coagulative necrosis with neutrophilic infiltrates is the histological finding of early changes after a myocardial infarction (MI). They are present 1–3 days post-MI. In an otherwise healthy adolescent girl without a history of congenital metabolic disease (e.g., familial hypercholesterolemia), myocardial infarction is extremely rare and very unlikely in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of myocardial tissue (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

The cardiomyocytes show hypereosinophilia (intense red staining), and there are interstitial red blood cells and intact neutrophils. Moreover, edema is visible, seen as clear spaces between cardiomyocytes.

These are early signs are of myocardial infarction (1–3 days old).

B) CORRECT:

Fibrinoid necrosis with histiocytic infiltrate describes the pathological appearance of Aschoff bodies, which are granulomas that form in the myocardium due to inflammation caused by rheumatic fever. They also typically contain Anitschkow cells, which are mononuclear cardiac histiocytes.

C) INCORRECT:

Deposits of misfolded protein aggregates can be found in myocardial biopsies affected by amyloidosis, which affects multiple organs and can cause restrictive cardiomyopathy (particularly AL amyloidosis). This leads to heart failure with presenting complaints such as edema and dyspnea, which are not present in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Myocardial infiltration with eosinophilic proteins is a histological finding of Loeffler endocarditis, a subtype of infiltrative cardiomyopathy. Loeffler endocarditis is associated with hypereosinophilic syndrome and causes restrictive cardiomyopathy. Unlike this case, patients present with symptoms of diastolic dysfunction like edema and dyspnea.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibrosis with myofibrillar disarray is a typical finding in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). This finding describes the loss of the normal histological architecture of myocardial tissue with cells arranged in swirls or clusters. HCM can also cause a systolic ejection murmur, as in this patient. However, other key findings, such as dyspnea on exertion, syncope, arrhythmias, and palpitations, are missing.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of myocardial tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

There is loss of the normal striated histological architecture of myocardial tissue, with most of the cells arranged in swirls or clusters (myofibrillar disarray).

Myofibrillar disarray is seen in a number of diseases, including hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.
questions.hint: Based upon the Jones criteria, this patient has 2 major criteria (subcutaneous nodules, heart murmur indicating valvulitis/carditis), which fulfill the requirements for a diagnosis of rheumatic fever. The diagnosis is further supported by her sore throat (presumably streptococcal pharyngitis) 3 weeks before and fever (a minor criterion).

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of a sore throat and fever. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Examination shows edematous oropharyngeal mucosa and enlarged tonsils with purulent exudate. There is tender cervical lymphadenopathy. If left untreated, which of the following conditions is most likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Toxic shock syndrome is caused by Staphylococcus aureus infection and typically presents with fevers, diffuse rash, and shock from an overwhelming inflammatory response triggered by toxic shock syndrome toxin. Toxigenic strains of group A Streptococcus infection can cause scarlet fever or a toxic shock-like syndrome but is not associated with the development of true toxic shock syndrome.
Image Description:

Multiple partly confluent macules and papules, measuring 1–5 mm in diameter, are visible on the skin of this patient's left arm.

This finding is consistent with a maculopapular exanthema (a diagnostic criterium of toxic shock syndrome) caused by staphylococcus aureus.

B) INCORRECT:

Polymyalgia rheumatica is an autoimmune disorder that typically presents with proximal muscle pain and stiffness (predominantly affecting the shoulders) and elevated inflammatory markers and is strongly associated with temporal arteritis. Polymyalgia rheumatica can resemble migratory polyarthritis, which is a possible complication of this patient's suspected GAS pharyngitis, but GAS pharyngitis is not associated with the development of polymyalgia rheumatica.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory condition characterized by polyarthritis and morning stiffness. This patient's GAS pharyngitis does increase her risk of acute rheumatic fever and migratory polyarthritis, but would not increase her risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis.

D) CORRECT:

Dilated cardiomyopathy is a potential late and serious complication of acute rheumatic fever, a type II hypersensitivity reaction that can occur within 1–5 weeks after untreated GAS pharyngitis. Rheumatic heart disease can manifest in several ways, including myocarditis, pericarditis, and valvular disease (mitral valve involvement is the most common). The development of dilated cardiomyopathy is multifactorial and usually occurs secondary to valvular disease, but can also result directly from myocarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

Erythema multiforme is a rash characterized by varying types of lesions, classically with target lesions (ring surrounding a dusky center). It is associated with several different infections, including Mycoplasma pneumoniae and HSV, as well as exposure to certain medications (phenytoin, NSAIDs, beta-lactam antibiotics, etc). GAS pharyngitis is associated with the development of erythema marginatum but is not a known cause of erythema multiforme.
Image Description:

Lower thigh and knee of a patient after antibiotic intake

Multiple erythematous, well-demarcated lesions can be seen. The lesions vary in size and shape, and some have merged to form larger lesions. The lesions show central erythema surrounded by a pale pink ring, characteristic of target lesions.
questions.hint: This patient has an acute infection of the oropharynx with odynophagia, fever, pharyngeal edema, cervical lymphadenopathy, and tonsillar hypertrophy with exudates. These features suggest group A streptococcal pharyngitis (GAS pharyngitis).

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 5-day history of fever, malaise, and joint pain. He had a sore throat 4 weeks ago that resolved without treatment. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F) and blood pressure is 84/62 mm Hg. Physical examination shows several firm, painless nodules under the skin near his elbows and the dorsal aspect of both wrists. Cardiopulmonary examination shows bilateral basilar crackles and a blowing, holosystolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex. Both knee joints are warm. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 129 mm/h. The immune response seen in this patient is most likely due to the presence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyaluronic acid capsule is a virulence factor of group A streptococcus (GAS) that inhibits phagocytosis. Although untreated infection with GAS can cause acute rheumatic fever, hyaluronic acid capsule is not thought to be responsible for this immunologic reaction.

Hyaluronic acid capsule should not be confused with hyaluronidase, another GAS virulence factor that facilitates tissue invasion.

B) INCORRECT:

Toxic shock syndrome toxin (TSST-1) is a virulence factor produced by Staphylococcus aureus that binds outside of the antigen binding site of T cell receptors and MHC II. It acts as a superantigen and induces the release of IL-1, IL-2, IFN-γ, and TNF-α, which can lead to staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome. This condition would cause widespread exanthem with skin peeling, myalgias, vomiting, and diarrhea. TSST-1 is not involved in the pathogenesis of rheumatic fever.

C) INCORRECT:

IgA protease is a bacterial virulence factor that cleaves IgA and allows bacteria to adhere to mucous membranes. It is produced by a number of gram‑positive and gram‑negative bacteria, e.g., S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and Neisseria spp. Although some of these pathogens can also cause acute pharyngitis, IgA protease is not involved in the pathogenesis of acute rheumatic fever.

D) INCORRECT:

CAMP factor is a pore-forming protein produced by group B streptococcus (GBS). CAMP factor is not essential for virulence, but it can be used to identify GBS (CAMP test). GBS infection is a common cause of meningitis, sepsis, and pneumonia in neonates, but it is not involved in the pathogenesis of rheumatic fever.

E) CORRECT:

M protein (virulence factor) is produced by group A streptococcus to prevent phagocytosis and inhibit the alternative pathway of the complement system and plays an important role in the autoimmune response that manifests with rheumatic fever. Without antibiotic treatment, antibody formation against streptococcal M protein can cause a type II hypersensitivity reaction. These antibodies cross-react with proteins of the heart, joints, and nerves, causing acute rheumatic fever.
questions.hint: Four weeks after a sore throat, the presence of fever, polyarthritis, subcutaneous nodules, and a murmur consistent with mitral valve regurgitation suggests rheumatic fever, a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of abnormal movements of his limbs. For the past 4 days, he has had uncontrolled jerking movements of his arms and legs and has been dropping cups and toys. His symptoms are worse when he is excited and improve while he is asleep. During the same time period, he has become increasingly irritable and tearful. He had a sore throat 6 weeks ago that resolved without treatment. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F). Examination shows occasional grimacing with involuntary jerking movements of his limbs. Muscle strength and tone are decreased in all extremities. When he grips the physician's index and middle fingers with his hands, his grip increases and decreases continuously. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Extraneural metastasis of a primary brain tumor such as medulloblastoma is rare. Large brain tumors can also manifest with gait abnormalities but typically would also be accompanied by features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headaches, early morning vomiting, papilledema), which are not seen in this patient. Additionally, repetitive jerking movements shortly after a pharyngeal infection is most consistent with Sydenham chorea, which is not due to malignancy and so not associated with metastasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Huntington disease is an autosomal-dominant neurocognitive disease that is characterized by repetitive movement disorders (chorea), psychiatric symptoms, and early-onset dementia. It is most commonly seen in patients with a family history of the disease. Although this patient's repetitive and jerky movements are typical of chorea, the onset of symptoms shortly after a pharyngeal infection suggests Sydenham chorea. Sydenham chorea is not associated with an increased risk of early-onset dementia.

C) INCORRECT:

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is strongly associated with Tourette syndrome, which is a neurological movement disorder characterized by multiple motor tics and at least one vocal tic. This patient lacks vocal tics and the motor tics in Tourette syndrome usually involve the facial muscles rather than the upper and the lower limbs seen here. This patient's repetitive movements and emotional lability are more consistent with Sydenham chorea, which is not associated with ADHD.

D) INCORRECT:

Friedreich ataxia is a neurodegenerative disease that most commonly manifests with diabetes mellitus, neurological dysfunction, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The neurological dysfunction seen in Friedreich ataxia may include weakness, poor coordination, and staggering gait but is not characterized by choreiform movements that improve with rest. Sydenham chorea, which this patient has, is not associated with the development of diabetes mellitus.

E) CORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is a complication of untreated group A streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis. Major manifestations of ARF include arthritis, Sydenham chorea, subcutaneous nodules, erythema marginatum, and cardiac valve disease, of which mitral valve involvement is most common. Valve disease occurs as a result of antibodies against bacterial M proteins cross-reacting with valvular self-antigens through a process known as molecular mimicry, which results in valvular destruction. The mechanism of Sydenham chorea is thought to be similar and result from antibody cross-reactivity with basal ganglia structures.

In the majority of cases, Sydenham chorea is self-limiting, with most patients seeing an improvement within a few weeks and nearly all patients fully recovered by six months.
questions.hint: In a pediatric patient with a recent history of a sore throat, random jerking movements, emotional lability, hypotonia, and a “milkmaid's grip” most likely indicate Sydenham chorea.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy from Eritrea is admitted to the hospital for lethargy and increased work of breathing. He has had recurrent episodes of fever, shortness of breath, and fatigue over the past 3 years. His pulse is 132/min and blood pressure is 90/66 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. Auscultation of the chest shows coarse crackles in both lungs and a diastolic murmur at the cardiac apex. Despite appropriate lifesaving measures, he dies. A photomicrograph of a section of myocardium obtained at autopsy is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's cardiac disease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infiltration of the myocardium by amastigotes is seen in patients with Chagas disease, which is caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. Chagas disease can manifest with fever (early sign), dyspnea, tachycardia, fatigue, hypoxia, and/or a heart murmur (later stages) and is characterized by eccentric cardiac hypertrophy with apical atrophy. However, an Aschoff body would not be expected on histological examination. Moreover, Chagas disease is endemic to Central and South America, not Eritrea.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Trypanosoma cruzi in a muscle tissue specimen (H&E stain; 1200x magnification)

An accumulation of Trypanosoma cruzi amastigotes can be seen within a striated muscle cell.

This tropical protozoan parasite causes Chagas disease, which often affects the myocardium.

B) INCORRECT:

A beta-myosin heavy chain defect is consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM), which can also manifest with dyspnea, tachycardia, fatigue, a decreased oxygen saturation, and a heart murmur. However, HOCM does not manifest with fever, and histological examination would show myofibrillar fibrosis and disarray, not an Aschoff body.

C) INCORRECT:

Caseating granulomatous inflammation is characteristic of tuberculosis, which should be suspected in a patient with a history of immigration, chronic fever, dyspnea, and fatigue, as seen here. Also, caseating granulomas have similar histological features, e.g., lymphocytes and histiocytes surrounding an area of central necrosis. However, myocardial involvement is extremely rare in tuberculosis. Moreover, the central necrotic region in caseating granulomas is composed of amorphous or granular necrotic debris, not the degenerated wavy fibers seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

The image shows a granuloma with necrosis in the center (green outline), a surrounding layer of immune cells such as macrophages (B), and a peripheral layer (C), which consists of epitheloid cells. A giant cell (A) can also be seen.

This is the typical histopathological appearance of a caseating granuloma, which is seen in tuberculosis.

D) CORRECT:

Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory sequela of untreated infection with group A streptococcus that can involve the heart (rheumatic heart disease), joints, skin, and CNS. The exact pathogenic mechanism that causes rheumatic fever is not fully understood, but it is believed to be due to a type II hypersensitivity reaction induced by streptococcal proteins. The antibodies formed then react with cardiac myosin proteins due to molecular mimicry between streptococcal M protein and human cardiac myosin, causing tissue inflammation and injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Exotoxin-mediated myonecrosis is characteristic of myocarditis caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae infection. Diphtheritic myocarditis can manifest with fever, dyspnea, tachycardia, fatigue, hypoxia, and a heart murmur. However, an autopsy would show a distorted myocardium with loss of striations and broad areas of granular degeneration, not an Aschoff body.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows an Aschoff body, which is composed of T cells, plasma cells, and cardiac histiocytes (Anitschkow cells) surrounding degenerated myofibers. Aschoff bodies are characteristic of rheumatic heart disease.

questions.text: A group of epidemiologists is studying the rates of cardiac surgeries performed in several Southeast Asian countries compared to the United States. Results show a significant increase in the number of mitral valve replacements performed in Vietnam in adults aged 30–50 years compared to the same age group in the United States. Which of the following public health interventions is most likely to decrease this number?

choices.text: Prompt antibiotic treatment for bacterial pharyngitis
Improved access to drug rehabilitation centers
Genetic screening program for FBN1 gene mutation
Screening echocardiography for prolapsed anterior mitral valve leaflets

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Prompt antibiotic treatment against established cases of group A streptococcal pharyngitis prevents the development of acute rheumatic fever and associated endocarditis. Acute rheumatic fever is the most common cause of mitral stenosis (MS). Severe cases of MS may require surgical valve replacement. Therefore, early antibiotic treatment of bacterial pharyngitis indirectly decreases the number of mitral valve replacements. Group A streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis is diagnosed either by throat culture or rapid strep test and is treated with penicillin V.

B) INCORRECT:

Improved access to drug rehabilitation centers is associated with a decreased incidence of recreational IV drug use, resulting in decreased septicemia and endocarditis. However, IV drug use-related endocarditis is primarily associated with S. aureus, Pseudomonas, and Candida infections of the tricuspid valve, not the mitral valve.

C) INCORRECT:

Genetic screening programs for FBN1 gene mutations allows for early detection of Marfan syndrome. Marfan syndrome predisposes to the development of mitral valve prolapse, which is susceptible to progress into mitral regurgitation. Severe mitral regurgitation is treated with mitral valve replacement. However, early detection of the syndrome neither alters the disease progression nor decreases the need for eventual mitral valve replacement.

D) INCORRECT:

Childhood vaccinations against Corynebacterium diphtheriae prevent the absorption and dissemination of diphtheria toxin throughout the body. The toxin is associated with cardiac tissue damage resulting in cardiac dilation and arrhythmias. However, diphtheria toxin is associated with myocarditis more than endocarditis (and subsequent valve destruction). Therefore, treatment of the disease would not significantly reduce the number of mitral valve replacements compared to other measures.

E) INCORRECT:

Echocardiographic screening for prolapsed anterior mitral valve leaflets allows for early detection of mitral valve prolapse (MVP) that occurs sporadically (primary MVP) or secondary to connective tissue disorders. MVP predisposes mitral valves to the development of mitral regurgitation and severe mitral regurgitation is treated with mitral valve replacement. However, early detection of MVP does not alter the disease course and would not decrease the number of mitral valve replacements.
questions.hint: The underlying cardiac illness in these patients is the most common cause of cardiovascular disease in children and adolescents in developing countries.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man who moved to the United States from Mexico one year ago reports a 6-month history of fatigue and increasing dyspnea on exertion. He states that he has not experienced fevers, cough, or weight loss. He recalls that at age 13, he was sick with fever, rash, and multiple painful joints several weeks after having a sore throat, but he never sought medical care for that illness.
Which one of the following cardiac murmurs is most likely to be found on this patient's physical examination?

choices.text: Systolic and diastolic machine-like murmur over the second left intercostal space
Midsystolic ejection murmur over the second right intercostal space
Holosystolic murmur, at the lower-left sternal border, that increases with inspiration
Harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur in the second left intercostal space, radiating to the neck

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Although rare in the United States, rheumatic fever is still endemic in many parts of the world, including Mexico. Acute rheumatic fever, which this patient has a history of, can manifest with symptoms such as fever, carditis, erythema marginatum, subcutaneous nodules, arthralgia or arthritis, and chorea. It is caused by pharyngitis due to a rheumatogenic strain of Streptococcus pyogenes.

Rheumatic heart disease is the most common late sequela of acute rheumatic fever. In young adults, it usually manifests as mitral regurgitation, which can be heard on physical examination as a holosystolic murmur that is particularly audible at the apex. In middle-aged and older patients with rheumatic heart disease, mixed mitral regurgitation and stenosis is common.

Key learning point: The cardiac murmur most likely to be heard in a young adult with a history of rheumatic fever who presents with dyspnea is one of mitral regurgitation (holosystolic murmur at the apex).

B) INCORRECT:

A systolic and diastolic machine-like murmur can be heard in patients with patent ductus arteriosus but is not typical in rheumatic heart disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis (midsystolic ejection murmur heard best over the second right intercostal space) is less common in rheumatic heart disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Isolated tricuspid regurgitation (holosystolic murmur at the lower-left sternal border that increases with inspiration) is unusual in a patient with rheumatic heart disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis (harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best over the second left intercostal space) is less common in rheumatic heart disease.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman presents for a physical before starting at a university, where she will live in a dormitory. She immigrated to the United States from Brazil 4 years ago. She was hospitalized twice for fevers and “a heart condition” at ages 7 and 12. She has a pronounced first heart sound and a faint mid-diastolic murmur at the apex.
A follow-up transthoracic echocardiogram shows mild left-atrial enlargement and a thickened calcified mitral valve suggestive of prior rheumatic heart disease.
Which one of the following antibiotic regimens is most appropriate for reducing this patient’s risk for further cardiac complications?

choices.text: Amoxicillin once daily for one year from the last attack
No preventive antibiotic treatment is indicated
Penicillin G benzathine intramuscular injection monthly until age 40
Cephalexin twice daily for 5 years after the last attack

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin and cephalexin are indicated for treating acute GAS pharyngitis but have not been well studied for their efficacy in secondary prevention.

The duration of antibiotic therapy depends on the severity of disease and the risk for recurrence. Patients such as this one, who have a history of carditis and residual valvular disease, require preventive antibiotics for 10 years after the last attack or until age 40, whichever is longer, not just one year from the last attack.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with a history of rheumatic fever who develop subsequent group A streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis are at high risk for recurrent attacks, with progression to rheumatic heart disease. GAS pharyngitis can be asymptomatic, so continuous antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent reinfection is recommended.

The duration of antibiotic therapy depends on the severity of disease and the risk for recurrence. Patients such as this one, who have a history of carditis and residual valvular disease, require preventive antibiotics for 10 years after the last attack or until age 40, whichever is longer.

C) CORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever is a complication of pharyngeal infection with group A streptococcus (GAS). Rheumatic heart disease is rare in the United States but is the leading cause of cardiovascular death during the first five decades of life in the developing world.

Patients with a history of rheumatic fever who develop subsequent GAS pharyngitis are at high risk for recurrent attacks, with progression to rheumatic heart disease. GAS pharyngitis can be asymptomatic, so continuous antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent reinfection is recommended.

The duration of antibiotic therapy depends on the severity of disease and the risk for recurrence. Patients such as this one, who have a history of carditis and residual valvular disease, require preventive antibiotics for 10 years after the last attack or until age 40, whichever is longer.

People with a history of rheumatic fever and carditis without valvular disease should receive prophylactic antibiotics for 10 years after the last attack or until age 21, whichever is longer. People with a history of acute rheumatic fever without carditis should receive antibiotics for 5 years after the last attack or until age 21, whichever is longer. Teachers, healthcare personnel, military recruits, and others living in crowded situations (e.g., college dormitories) are at increased risk for exposure and recurrence.

The recommended antibiotics for secondary prevention of rheumatic fever include long-acting penicillin G benzathine intramuscular injections every 3 to 4 weeks, daily oral penicillin V, sulfadiazine, or a macrolide antibiotic, such as azithromycin.

Key learning point: For a patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease and valvular sequelae, secondary antibiotic prophylaxis should continue for 10 years or until 40 years of age, whichever is longer.

D) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin and cephalexin are indicated for treating acute group A streptococcus pharyngitis but have not been well studied for their efficacy in secondary prevention.

The duration of antibiotic therapy depends on the severity of disease and the risk for recurrence. Patients such as this one, who have a history of carditis and residual valvular disease, require preventive antibiotics for 10 years after the last attack or until age 40, whichever is longer, not just 5 years after the last attack.

E) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin and cephalexin are indicated for treating acute group A streptococcus pharyngitis but have not been well studied for their efficacy in secondary prevention.

The duration of antibiotic therapy depends on the severity of disease and the risk for recurrence. Patients such as this one, who have a history of carditis and residual valvular disease, require preventive antibiotics for 10 years after the last attack or until age 40, whichever is longer, not just until age 21.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl is hospitalized because she has severe joint pain that makes it difficult for her to walk. Her mother states that the pain seems to move around the girl’s body, alternately involving her knees, elbows, and wrists. Ibuprofen has provided modest relief. Three weeks ago, the girl developed a sore throat, but she has otherwise been well.
Her temperature is 39.5°C, her heart rate is 92 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and her blood pressure is 92/48 mm Hg. Both knees are warm, and there is swelling at the joint lines. In addition, her left ankle is swollen and exquisitely tender, and her hip has a diminished range of motion.
Her leukocyte count is 16,300 per mm3 (reference range, 5000–14,500), and her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 72 mm/hour (0–20).
What testing is most likely to be diagnostic in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor (RF) may be positive in cases of polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). However, RF-positive polyarticular JIA tends to occur in children older than 9 years and commonly involves small joints. Furthermore, the presence of fever in this case argues against this diagnosis.

Both ANA levels and RF might be ordered as part of a comprehensive workup to evaluate for a wide differential, but the clinical scenario better fits acute rheumatic fever.

B) INCORRECT:

Lyme disease is usually monoarticular when involving the knee and sometimes the hip. Arthritis is a late manifestation of Lyme disease. Children affected by Lyme disease typically present with isolated knee swelling, without erythema and fever.

C) CORRECT:

The combination of fever, migratory polyarthritis, and elevated inflammatory markers is most consistent with a diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever.

Acute rheumatic fever is an inflammatory condition that develops as a sequela of recent group A streptococcal pharyngitis. Rheumatic heart disease is the most common cause of acquired heart disease in children worldwide and can be prevented with effective antibiotic treatment of pharyngitis related to group A streptococcus.

Diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever requires a preceding group A beta-hemolytic streptococcal (GABHS) infection, documented by a positive throat culture, positive rapid streptococcal antigen tests, or an elevated or rising streptococcal antibody titer (ASO or DNase B). Diagnosis also requires the presence of two major JONES criteria or one major and two minor JONES criteria.

The major JONES criteria correspond to the following clinical manifestations:

• J = Joints, typically a migratory polyarthritis.
• O = Obvious (heart). The carditis in acute rheumatic fever can involve all levels of the myocardium, but usually there is valvular involvement.
• N = Nodules. Subcutaneous nodules are rarely seen, only in the most severe cases of ARF. They are located on the joints, scalp, and spinous processes of the thoracic and lumbar vertebrae.
• E = Erythema marginatum. This is a serpiginous, blanching, nonitchy red rash with well-demarcated borders. It is located on the trunk and extremities, typically not on the face.
• S = Sydenham’s chorea. Chorea is a neuropsychiatric manifestation of purposeless, involuntary movements of the trunk and extremities.

The minor JONES criteria are arthralgia, fever ≥38°C, elevated acute-phase reactants (sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, or total leukocyte count), and a prolonged PR interval.

This patient meets one major JONES criterion: a migratory polyarthritis. She also has two minor JONES criteria: fever ≥38°C and elevated inflammatory markers. Evidence of GABHS, such as from an antistreptolysin O titer, is necessary to confirm a diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever in this patient.

Key learning point: In addition to fulfilling JONES criteria, a diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever requires documentation of prior infection with group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient’s leukocyte count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are elevated. Measuring C-reactive protein, another nonspecific inflammatory marker, will not pinpoint the diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibody (ANA) levels are elevated in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although joint pain and fever are seen in patients with SLE, the patient in this case lacks many of the other diagnostic features of SLE. In addition, SLE would be very unusual in a child <10 years of age.

Both ANA levels and RF might be ordered as part of a comprehensive workup to evaluate for a wide differential, but the clinical scenario better fits acute rheumatic fever.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl presents for a physical before starting at a boarding school, where she will live in a dormitory. She immigrated to the United States from Brazil 2 years ago. She was hospitalized twice for fevers and “a heart condition” at ages 7 and 12. She has a pronounced first heart sound and a faint mid-diastolic murmur at the apex.
A follow-up transthoracic echocardiogram shows mild left-atrial enlargement and a thickened calcified mitral valve suggestive of prior rheumatic heart disease.
Which one of the following antibiotic regimens is most appropriate for reducing this patient’s risk for further cardiac complications?

choices.text: Penicillin G benzathine intramuscular injection monthly until age 40
Amoxicillin once daily for one year from the last attack
Cephalexin twice daily for 5 years after the last attack
No preventive antibiotic treatment is indicated

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever is a complication of pharyngeal infection with group A streptococcus (GAS). Rheumatic heart disease is rare in the United States but is the leading cause of cardiovascular death during the first five decades of life in the developing world.

Patients with a history of rheumatic fever who develop subsequent GAS pharyngitis are at high risk for recurrent attacks, with progression to rheumatic heart disease. GAS pharyngitis can be asymptomatic, so continuous antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent reinfection is recommended.

The duration of antibiotic therapy depends on the severity of disease and the risk for recurrence. Patients such as this one, who have a history of carditis and residual valvular disease, require preventive antibiotics for 10 years after the last attack or until age 40, whichever is longer. People with a history of rheumatic fever and carditis without valvular disease should receive prophylactic antibiotics for 10 years after the last attack or until age 21, whichever is longer. People with a history of acute rheumatic fever without carditis should receive antibiotics for 5 years after the last attack or until age 21, whichever is longer. Teachers, healthcare personnel, military recruits, and others living in crowded situations (e.g., dormitories) are at increased risk for exposure and recurrence.

The recommended antibiotics for secondary prevention of rheumatic fever include long-acting penicillin G benzathine intramuscular injections every 3 to 4 weeks, daily oral penicillin V, sulfadiazine, or a macrolide antibiotic, such as azithromycin.

Key learning point: For a patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease and valvular sequelae, secondary antibiotic prophylaxis should continue for 10 years or until 40 years of age, whichever is longer.

B) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin is indicated for treating acute group A streptococcus pharyngitis but has not been well studied for its efficacy in secondary prevention.

C) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin is indicated for treating acute group A streptococcus pharyngitis but has not been well studied for its efficacy in secondary prevention.

D) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin is indicated for treating acute group A streptococcus pharyngitis but has not been well studied for its efficacy in secondary prevention.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with a history of rheumatic fever who develop subsequent group A streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis are at high risk for recurrent attacks, with progression to rheumatic heart disease. GAS pharyngitis can be asymptomatic, so continuous antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent reinfection is recommended.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy who moved to the United States from Mexico one year ago reports a 6-month history of fatigue and increasing dyspnea on exertion. He states that he has not experienced fevers, cough, or weight loss. He recalls that at age 12 he was sick with fever, rash, and multiple painful joints several weeks after having a sore throat, but he never sought medical care for that illness.
Which one of the following cardiac murmurs is most likely to be found on this patient's physical examination?

choices.text: Systolic and diastolic machine-like murmur over the second left intercostal space
Holosystolic murmur, at the lower-left sternal border, that increases with inspiration
Harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur in the second left intercostal space, radiating to the neck
Midsystolic ejection murmur over the second right intercostal space

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A systolic and diastolic machine-like murmur can be heard in patients with patent ductus arteriosus but is not typical in rheumatic heart disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Isolated tricuspid regurgitation (holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border that increases with inspiration) is unusual in a patient with rheumatic heart disease.

C) CORRECT:

Although rare in the United States, rheumatic fever is still endemic in many parts of the world, including Mexico. Acute rheumatic fever, which this patient has a history of, can manifest with symptoms such as fever, carditis, erythema marginatum, subcutaneous nodules, arthralgia or arthritis, and chorea. It is caused by pharyngitis due to a rheumatogenic strain of Streptococcus pyogenes.

Rheumatic heart disease is the most common late sequela of acute rheumatic fever. In adolescents and young adults, it usually manifests as mitral regurgitation, which can be heard on physical examination as a holosystolic murmur that is particularly audible at the apex. In middle-aged and older patients with rheumatic heart disease, mixed mitral regurgitation and stenosis is common.

Key learning point: The cardiac murmur most likely to be heard in an adolescent with a history of rheumatic fever who presents with dyspnea is one of mitral regurgitation (holosystolic murmur at the apex).

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis (harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best over the second left intercostal space) is also less common in rheumatic heart disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis (midsystolic ejection murmur heard best over the second right intercostal space) is less common in rheumatic heart disease.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with pain, redness, and swelling of the left knee for the past day. She has had no recent fevers, rash, congestion, diarrhea, or neurologic symptoms. She was diagnosed with a viral pharyngitis 3 weeks ago and received supportive care. Last week, she had pain and swelling of the right wrist that she thought was related to the start of volleyball season. The pain resolved after 48 hours of ibuprofen, which the patient then discontinued. She did not seek medical care at the time. She has no family history of autoimmune disease.
On examination, she has a temperature of 37.4°C, a heart rate of 102 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 100/72 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. She appears generally tired but nontoxic. Cardiac examination reveals a 2/6 blowing holosystolic murmur, best heard at the cardiac apex, with radiation to the left axilla. Both lungs are clear to auscultation. There is no hepatosplenomegaly and no rashes or skin nodules. The patient has 2+ distal pulses with a capillary refill time of <2 seconds. Her left knee is slightly warm and tender to palpation, with moderate swelling and erythema.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
7000
4500–13,500


Platelet count (per mm3)
175,000
150,000–450,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
12.0
11.5–15.5


C-reactive protein (mg/liter)
48
0–5


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hr)
77
0–10


A rapid streptococcal test is negative and serum anti-deoxyribonuclease B antibody testing and antistreptolysin O titers are positive. Blood and synovial-fluid culture results are pending. A joint aspirate reveals clear fluid with a negative Gram stain and normal erythrocyte and leukocyte counts.
A chest radiograph is normal. An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia with a normal PR interval and borderline low voltage. An echocardiogram shows normal biventricular structure and function, a structurally normal mitral valve with mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation, no aortic regurgitation, and no pericardial effusion.
A 600,000-unit dose of benzathine penicillin G is administered.
Which one of the following additional treatments, if any, is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient does not require additional treatment for her mild carditis. There is no evidence that antiinflammatory treatment improves cardiac outcomes in acute rheumatic fever. Despite lack of evidence, many clinicians treat patients who have severe carditis (cardiomegaly, heart failure, third-degree heart block) with glucocorticoids. Prednisone for 2 weeks followed by a taper is a common regimen in such cases. If heart failure is present, routine management should be performed.

B) INCORRECT:

Rheumatologic diseases are part of the differential diagnosis for migrating polyarthritis, but this patient does not currently meet diagnostic criteria for any rheumatologic disease. Therefore, treatment with methotrexate is not indicated.

C) CORRECT:

This patient is presenting with acute rheumatic fever with migrating polyarthritis and carditis.

Although acute rheumatic fever is extremely prevalent in developing countries, it remains relatively rare in the United States. Major diagnostic criteria include polyarthritis, carditis, chorea, erythema marginatum, and subcutaneous nodules; minor criteria include fever ≥38°C, arthralgia, elevated acute-phase reactants, and a prolonged PR interval on electrocardiogram. The diagnosis of an initial episode of acute rheumatic fever is made when there is evidence of a preceding streptococcal infection together with either 2 major criteria or 1 major and 2 minor criteria. In this case, the patient has evidence of a preceding streptococcal infection, plus polyarthritis and mild carditis (2 major criteria).

Migratory polyarthritis in acute rheumatic fever is the most common major criterion, affecting 40% to 70% of patients. Classically, the arthritis migrates from large joint to large joint, and the affected joints are erythematous, swollen, and tender. In almost all cases (including this patient’s wrist pain), the arthritis responds to nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) within 48 to 72 hours.

Approximately 30% to 70% of patients with acute rheumatic fever develop carditis, typically within the first 2 weeks. Traditionally, the carditis in acute rheumatic fever has been described as a pancarditis. The mitral and aortic valves are most commonly affected, with mitral involvement found in 95% of cases with acute rheumatic carditis. The carditis can range from mild (usually asymptomatic from the mitral regurgitation, as in this patient) to severe (with accompanying cardiomegaly, heart failure, and third-degree heart block).

The treatment of acute rheumatic fever is initially focused on eradicating the streptococcal infection and then preventing any recurrence. In this case, the patient appropriately received a dose of long-acting penicillin in the emergency department to eliminate the streptococcal infection; she will require secondary prophylaxis every 21 to 28 days. In addition, symptomatic treatment is required. The symptoms associated with polyarthritis often improve significantly with NSAID use. High-dose aspirin (80 mg/kg/day) has been the most well-studied NSAID in acute rheumatic fever, and it is reasonable as a first-line antiinflammatory in this circumstance. Some experts recommend treatment for 4 to 6 weeks. Newer antiinflammatory agents, such as naproxen, are increasingly used instead of aspirin, given emerging data of similar efficacy.

Key learning point: In a patient with acute rheumatic fever with migratory polyarthritis and mild carditis, the most appropriate initial treatment after administration of appropriate antibiotics is high-dose aspirin.

D) INCORRECT:

Initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics (such as vancomycin and gentamicin) for presumed infective endocarditis (IE) is not appropriate for this patient, as she does not meet the major diagnostic criteria for IE (endocardial involvement and positive blood cultures) or the minor criteria (predisposing heart condition, fever, vascular phenomena, or immunologic phenomena). Clinically, it would be unusual for a patient with IE to present without fever, as this patient has done.

E) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient has symptoms, supportive care should be provided, and treatment with aspirin is indicated given the elevated inflammatory markers. Providing no additional treatment would be inappropriate.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the office by his father because of abnormal movements of his limbs. For the past 4 days, he has had uncontrolled jerking movements of his arms and legs and has been dropping cups and toys. His symptoms are worse when he is excited and improve while he is asleep. During the same time period, he has become increasingly irritable and tearful. He had a sore throat 6 weeks ago that resolved without treatment. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F). Examination shows occasional grimacing with involuntary jerking movements of his limbs. Muscle strength and tone are decreased in all extremities. When he grips the physician's index and middle fingers with his hands, his grip increases and decreases continuously. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Extraneural metastasis of a primary brain tumor such as medulloblastoma is rare. Large brain tumors can also manifest with gait abnormalities but typically would also be accompanied by features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headaches, early morning vomiting, papilledema), which are not seen in this patient. Additionally, repetitive jerking movements shortly after a pharyngeal infection is most consistent with Sydenham chorea, which is not due to malignancy and so not associated with metastasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Huntington disease is an autosomal-dominant neurocognitive disease that is characterized by repetitive movement disorders (chorea), psychiatric symptoms, and early-onset dementia. It is most commonly seen in patients with a family history of the disease. Although this patient's repetitive and jerky movements are typical of chorea, the onset of symptoms shortly after a pharyngeal infection suggests Sydenham chorea. Sydenham chorea is not associated with an increased risk of early-onset dementia.

C) INCORRECT:

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is strongly associated with Tourette syndrome, which is a neurological movement disorder characterized by multiple motor tics and at least one vocal tic. This patient lacks vocal tics and the motor tics in Tourette syndrome usually involve the facial muscles rather than the upper and the lower limbs seen here. This patient's repetitive movements and emotional lability are more consistent with Sydenham chorea, which is not associated with ADHD.

D) INCORRECT:

Friedreich ataxia is a neurodegenerative disease that most commonly manifests with diabetes mellitus, neurological dysfunction, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The neurological dysfunction seen in Friedreich ataxia may include weakness, poor coordination, and staggering gait but is not characterized by choreiform movements that improve with rest. Sydenham chorea, which this patient has, is not associated with the development of diabetes mellitus.

E) CORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is a complication of untreated group A streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis. Major manifestations of ARF include arthritis, Sydenham chorea, subcutaneous nodules, erythema marginatum, and cardiac valve disease, of which mitral valve involvement is most common. Valve disease occurs as a result of antibodies against bacterial M proteins cross-reacting with valvular self-antigens through a process known as molecular mimicry, which results in valvular destruction. The mechanism of Sydenham chorea is thought to be similar and result from antibody cross-reactivity with basal ganglia structures.

In the majority of cases, Sydenham chorea is self-limiting, with most patients seeing an improvement within a few weeks and nearly all patients fully recovered by six months.
questions.hint: In a pediatric patient with a recent history of a sore throat, random jerking movements, emotional lability, hypotonia, and a “milkmaid's grip” most likely indicate Sydenham chorea.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of progressively worsening shortness of breath for 3 days. He has had fever and malaise for the past 5 days. He had a sore throat 3 weeks ago that resolved without treatment. He appears ill. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 98/min and blood pressure is 84/62 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Examination shows jugular venous distension and bilateral ankle edema. There are erythematous, ring-shaped macules and patches over his trunk that are well-demarcated. Auscultation of the chest shows crackles at the lung bases bilaterally. An S3 gallop is heard. An x-ray of the chest shows cardiac silhouette enlargement with prominent vascular markings in both lung fields. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms (dyspnea, jugular venous distension, bilateral ankle edema, S3 gallop) and chest x-ray findings (enlarged cardiac silhouette, prominent vascular markings) suggest acute heart failure most likely due to carditis. His well-demarcated, erythematous, ring-shaped macules and patches are consistent with erythema marginatum. In the context of his recently untreated sore throat (most likely due to a group A streptococcal infection), the presence of carditis and erythema marginatum (two of the major revised Jones criteria) is consistent with acute rheumatic fever.

B) INCORRECT:

Viral myocarditis can also manifest with symptoms of heart failure. While this patient has jugular venous distention, ankle edema, and x-ray findings consistent with heart failure, his rash (erythema marginatum) suggests an alternative etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Rash is one of the most common presenting symptoms of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which can also affect all layers of the heart (pancarditis). However, the rash seen in SLE is typically a malar rash or discoid rash, as opposed to the rash in this patient, which is suggestive of erythema marginatum. Other common features of SLE which are not present in this patient include arthritis, arthralgia, and/or fatigue.

D) INCORRECT:

Lyme disease can manifest with a ring-like rash with central clearing (erythema migrans) and can also cause carditis. However, Lyme carditis typically manifests as a new cardiac arrhythmia (AV block, sudden death) and rarely as congestive heart failure due to pericarditis. Furthermore, Lyme carditis is a late manifestation of disseminated disease and unlikely to occur simultaneously with the rash.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has had a fever for the past 5 days, which is a key diagnostic feature of Kawasaki disease. Although myocarditis is a known complication of Kawasaki disease and can manifest with signs of congestive heart failure, this patient lacks other salient symptoms of Kawasaki disease such as mucositis, lymphadenopathy, and conjunctivitis. Furthermore, his skin rash is not desquamative but is rather suggestive of erythema marginatum.
questions.hint: Other common sequelae of this patient's condition include arthritis, subcutaneous nodules, and chorea.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother because of a 2-day history of high fever and swelling of the left ankle and knee. She had a sore throat 3 weeks ago. There is no family history of serious illness. She developed an episode of breathlessness and generalized rash when she received dicloxacillin for a skin infection 2 years ago. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38.8°C (102.3°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 98/62 mm Hg. Examination shows swelling and tenderness of the left ankle and knee; range of motion is limited. Lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best at the apex. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Macrolides such as clarithromycin are the antibiotics of choice for ARF in patients with hypersensitivity to beta-lactam antibiotics. In addition to group A streptococcal eradication therapy, patients with ARF also require symptomatic treatment with NSAIDs for arthritis and fever.

Additionally, an echocardiogram should be performed to evaluate for the presence of rheumatic valvulitis. This patient's apical holosystolic murmur is consistent with mitral regurgitation (likely due to rheumatic valvulitis).

B) INCORRECT:

Low-dose glucocorticoids (not high-dose) may be used for the management of pain and fever in ARF if NSAIDs fail. As this patient is only 12 years old and is febrile, ibuprofen or naproxen should be first administered (aspirin is contraindicated due to the risk of Reye syndrome) instead.

C) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin is a good alternative to penicillin V (the drug of choice) for ARF in children because the taste in oral suspension is better tolerated. However, amoxicillin is contraindicated in this case because the patient has a history of a hypersensitivity reaction to dicloxacillin, which belongs to the same class of drugs (penicillins).

D) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline, a tetracycline, is indicated for the treatment of Lyme disease. Although polyarthritis and cardiac involvement could be suggestive of Lyme disease, this diagnosis is unlikely because the patient has no history of erythema migrans, tick bites, or outdoor stay in a Lyme-endemic region.
