This patient's presentation is consistent with ARF, which is most commonly caused by group A streptococcal (GAS) infection. GAS has developed widespread resistance to tetracyclines, which renders them ineffective for the treatment of ARF.

E) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate, an antimetabolite, may be administered to treat rheumatologic diseases, such as juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), which is consistent with this patient's polyarthritis. However, she does not have any extraarticular manifestations (e.g., uveitis, rashes, nail changes, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly), making JIA an unlikely diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient had a recent sore throat (presumably due to a group A streptococcal infection) and now presents with valvulitis and polyarthritis (two of the major revised Jones criteria), the combination of which is consistent with acute rheumatic fever (ARF). This patient's hypersensitivity to penicillins should be taken into consideration when choosing the appropriate pharmacotherapy.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is hospitalized because she has severe joint pain that makes it difficult for her to walk. Her mother states that the pain seems to move around the girl’s body, alternately involving her knees, elbows, and wrists. Ibuprofen has provided modest relief. Three weeks ago, the girl developed a sore throat, but she has otherwise been well. Her temperature is 39.5°C, her heart rate is 92 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and her blood pressure is 92/48 mm Hg. Both knees are warm, and there is swelling at the joint lines. In addition, her left ankle is swollen and exquisitely tender, and her hip has a diminished range of motion. Her leukocyte count is 16,300 per mm3 (reference range, 5000–14,500), and her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 72 mm/hour (0–20). What testing is most likely to be diagnostic in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor (RF) may be positive in cases of polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). However, RF-positive polyarticular JIA tends to occur in children older than 9 years and commonly involves small joints. Furthermore, the presence of fever in this case argues against this diagnosis.

Both ANA levels and RF might be ordered as part of a comprehensive workup to evaluate for a wide differential, but the clinical scenario better fits acute rheumatic fever.

B) INCORRECT:

Lyme disease is usually monoarticular when involving the knee and sometimes the hip. Arthritis is a late manifestation of Lyme disease. Children affected by Lyme disease typically present with isolated knee swelling, without erythema and fever.

C) CORRECT:

The combination of fever, migratory polyarthritis, and elevated inflammatory markers is most consistent with a diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever.

Acute rheumatic fever is an inflammatory condition that develops as a sequela of recent group A streptococcal pharyngitis. Rheumatic heart disease is the most common cause of acquired heart disease in children worldwide and can be prevented with effective antibiotic treatment of pharyngitis related to group A streptococcus.

Diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever requires a preceding group A beta-hemolytic streptococcal (GABHS) infection, documented by a positive throat culture, positive rapid streptococcal antigen tests, or an elevated or rising streptococcal antibody titer (ASO or DNase B). Diagnosis also requires the presence of two major JONES criteria or one major and two minor JONES criteria.

The major JONES criteria correspond to the following clinical manifestations:

• J = Joints, typically a migratory polyarthritis.
• O = Obvious (heart). The carditis in acute rheumatic fever can involve all levels of the myocardium, but usually there is valvular involvement.
• N = Nodules. Subcutaneous nodules are rarely seen, only in the most severe cases of ARF. They are located on the joints, scalp, and spinous processes of the thoracic and lumbar vertebrae.
• E = Erythema marginatum. This is a serpiginous, blanching, nonitchy red rash with well-demarcated borders. It is located on the trunk and extremities, typically not on the face.
• S = Sydenham’s chorea. Chorea is a neuropsychiatric manifestation of purposeless, involuntary movements of the trunk and extremities.

The minor JONES criteria are arthralgia, fever ≥38°C, elevated acute-phase reactants (sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, or total leukocyte count), and a prolonged PR interval.

This patient meets one major JONES criterion: a migratory polyarthritis. She also has two minor JONES criteria: fever ≥38°C and elevated inflammatory markers. Evidence of GABHS, such as from an antistreptolysin O titer, is necessary to confirm a diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever in this patient.

Key learning point: In addition to fulfilling JONES criteria, a diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever requires documentation of prior infection with group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient’s leukocyte count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are elevated. Measuring C-reactive protein, another nonspecific inflammatory marker, will not pinpoint the diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibody (ANA) levels are elevated in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although joint pain and fever are seen in patients with SLE, the patient in this case lacks many of the other diagnostic features of SLE. In addition, SLE would be very unusual in a child <10 years of age.

Both ANA levels and RF might be ordered as part of a comprehensive workup to evaluate for a wide differential, but the clinical scenario better fits acute rheumatic fever.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the office for a 6-month history of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. He immigrated to the United States 35 years ago from India. His pulse is 89/min and blood pressure is 145/60 mm Hg. Crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur loudest at the left sternal border in the third intercostal space. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is seen in patients with aortic stenosis, which can present with angina, syncope, and heart failure. Aortic stenosis is characterized by a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur, unlike the diastolic murmur heard in this patient. Pulsus parvus et tardus is not a typical feature of aortic regurgitation.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulsus paradoxus is characterized by decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration and is classically seen in patients with cardiac tamponade and/or constrictive pericarditis. Pulsus paradoxus is not a feature of aortic regurgitation.

C) INCORRECT:

Fixed splitting of S2 most commonly occurs as a result of pathologic processes that increase right ventricular volume (thereby delaying pulmonic valve closure), such as an atrial septal defect. Fixed splitting of S2 is not characteristic of aortic regurgitation.

D) CORRECT:

A water hammer pulse is a classic finding on cardiovascular examination in patients with significant aortic regurgitation, and results from the rapid ejection of a large stroke volume into a low-pressure arterial system. Other findings in patients with aortic regurgitation may include pulse-synchronous head nodding (de Musset sign) and Austin Flint murmur.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical splitting of S2 refers to the pathological closure of the pulmonary valve before the aortic valve, resulting in an S2 split with expiration (instead of the physiologic splitting of S2 heard normally with inspiration). Paradoxical splitting is caused by conditions that delay left ventricular outflow, such as aortic stenosis or left bundle branch block. It is not typically heard in aortic regurgitation.
Image Description:

P2 precedes A2 (audible during expiration but not inspiration).

Certain conditions (e.g., aortic stenosis, left bundle branch block) delay the closure of the aortic valve, resulting in P2 preceding A2. In inspiration, P2 is also delayed (physiological), causing a paradoxical decrease in the split.

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of left heart failure, a high pulse pressure, and an early diastolic murmur at Erb's point (left sternal border, third intercostal space), which suggests chronic aortic regurgitation (AR). Based on his history of emigration from India, this patient likely has rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of AR in developing countries.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man who moved to the United States from Mexico one year ago reports a 6-month history of fatigue and increasing dyspnea on exertion. He states that he has not experienced fevers, cough, or weight loss. He recalls that at age 13, he was sick with fever, rash, and multiple painful joints several weeks after having a sore throat, but he never sought medical care for that illness. Which one of the following cardiac murmurs is most likely to be found on this patient's physical examination?

choices.text: Systolic and diastolic machine-like murmur over the second left intercostal space
Midsystolic ejection murmur over the second right intercostal space
Holosystolic murmur, at the lower-left sternal border, that increases with inspiration
Harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur in the second left intercostal space, radiating to the neck

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Although rare in the United States, rheumatic fever is still endemic in many parts of the world, including Mexico. Acute rheumatic fever, which this patient has a history of, can manifest with symptoms such as fever, carditis, erythema marginatum, subcutaneous nodules, arthralgia or arthritis, and chorea. It is caused by pharyngitis due to a rheumatogenic strain of Streptococcus pyogenes.

Rheumatic heart disease is the most common late sequela of acute rheumatic fever. In young adults, it usually manifests as mitral regurgitation, which can be heard on physical examination as a holosystolic murmur that is particularly audible at the apex. In middle-aged and older patients with rheumatic heart disease, mixed mitral regurgitation and stenosis is common.

Key learning point: The cardiac murmur most likely to be heard in a young adult with a history of rheumatic fever who presents with dyspnea is one of mitral regurgitation (holosystolic murmur at the apex).

B) INCORRECT:

A systolic and diastolic machine-like murmur can be heard in patients with patent ductus arteriosus but is not typical in rheumatic heart disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis (midsystolic ejection murmur heard best over the second right intercostal space) is less common in rheumatic heart disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Isolated tricuspid regurgitation (holosystolic murmur at the lower-left sternal border that increases with inspiration) is unusual in a patient with rheumatic heart disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis (harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best over the second left intercostal space) is less common in rheumatic heart disease.

questions.text: A 23-year-old with rheumatic fever and mitral regurgitation asks about prophylaxis duration. What is the most appropriate recommendation?

choices.text: Continue prophylaxis at least 10 years or until age 40, whichever is longer
Limit prophylaxis to 5 years to minimize antibiotic exposure
Continue prophylaxis only until successive echocardiograms appear normal
Discontinue prophylaxis immediately if valvular symptoms fully resolve

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with rheumatic fever and carditis, such as mitral regurgitation, are at high risk for recurrent episodes and further cardiac damage. Guidelines recommend extended prophylaxis for at least 10 years or until age 40, whichever is longer, to protect against reinfection and prevent additional valvular injury. This approach minimizes the risk of immune-mediated cardiac damage and supports long-term cardiac health.

Key learning point: For patients with rheumatic fever and carditis with residual heart disease, prophylaxis is recommended until at least 10 years after the last episode or until age 40, whichever is longer.

B) INCORRECT:

Limiting prophylaxis to 5 years may reduce antibiotic use but does not address the ongoing risk of recurrent rheumatic fever in patients with valvular damage. Prolonged prophylaxis is necessary to prevent further valve damage and long-term cardiovascular sequelae.

C) INCORRECT:

Echocardiographic improvement does not necessarily indicate reduced risk for recurrent rheumatic fever. Structural valve changes, such as fibrosis, may be permanent and not regress on imaging. Prophylaxis duration is based on recurrence risk and residual valvular dysfunction, not imaging findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Symptomatic improvement does not eliminate the risk of recurrent rheumatic fever in patients with valvular involvement. Prophylaxis is based on the presence of rheumatic carditis and structural damage, not symptom resolution, to prevent further cardiac injury.

questions.text: A 14-year-old with a recent streptococcal infection presents with migratory joint swelling over knees and wrists, a new holosystolic murmur, and subcutaneous nodules. Which finding is a minor Jones criterion in low-risk populations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythema marginatum, a distinctive rash with pink rings and a clear center, is a major Jones criterion for acute rheumatic fever. Major criteria include carditis, polyarthritis, Sydenham chorea, subcutaneous nodules, and erythema marginatum.

B) CORRECT:

In acute rheumatic fever, the Jones criteria include major and minor manifestations. Polyarthralgia, defined as joint pain without overt swelling or redness, is a minor criterion in low-risk populations. Other minor criteria include fever, elevated acute phase reactants (e.g., erythrocyte sedimentation rate [ESR], C-reactive protein [CRP]), and prolonged PR interval on electrocardiogram. These minor criteria support the diagnosis when combined with major criteria, indicating an immune response following a group A streptococcal infection.

Key learning point: Polyarthralgia is considered a minor manifestation of rheumatic fever according to the Jones criteria, while pancarditis, Sydenham chorea, and subcutaneous nodules are major manifestations.

C) INCORRECT:

Sydenham chorea, characterized by rapid, involuntary movements, is a major Jones criterion for acute rheumatic fever. It is pathognomonic for the condition and strongly associated with the autoimmune response to group A streptococcus.

D) INCORRECT:

Pancarditis, involving inflammation of all heart layers, is a manifestation of carditis and a major Jones criterion in acute rheumatic fever. Minor criteria include fever, arthralgia, elevated acute phase reactants, and prolonged PR interval on ECG.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with 2 weeks of migratory joint pain involving the knees and wrists. He had a sore throat 3 weeks earlier but did not seek medical attention. He has subcutaneous nodules over the extensor surfaces of his arms. Cardiac auscultation is normal.

Temperature
38.5°C

Which of the following is the most appropriate test to confirm the suspected underlying cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Borrelia burgdorferi serology diagnoses Lyme disease, which presents with tick exposure, erythema migrans rash, and possibly monoarthritis. The patient's history of sore throat, fever, and subcutaneous nodules suggests a post-streptococcal process, not Lyme disease, making this test unsuitable.

B) CORRECT:

Antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers detect antibodies against the streptolysin O antigen from group A Streptococcus. This test is crucial for confirming a recent streptococcal infection, which can lead to rheumatic fever. The patient's migratory joint pain, subcutaneous nodules, and fever, following a sore throat, suggest rheumatic fever. ASO titers typically rise a few weeks post-infection, aligning with the clinical presentation and supporting the diagnosis of a post-streptococcal immune response.

Key learning point: Elevated antistreptolysin O titer is used to confirm a recent streptococcal infection, which is associated with rheumatic fever, characterized by painful swollen joints and subcutaneous nodules in children.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor (RF) is used in diagnosing rheumatoid arthritis and some juvenile idiopathic arthritis forms. The patient's migratory joint pain, fever, and subcutaneous nodules following a sore throat indicate a post-streptococcal process, not autoimmune arthritis, making RF testing irrelevant.

D) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are used to screen for autoimmune diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus, characterized by multi-system involvement and specific rashes. The patient's symptoms, including migratory joint pain and a history of sore throat, suggest a post-streptococcal process rather than an autoimmune condition, making ANA testing inappropriate.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. He immigrated from India 35 years ago. His pulse is 89/min and blood pressure is 145/60 mm Hg. On examination, crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination reveals a grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur, loudest at the left sternal border in the third intercostal space. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is seen in patients with aortic stenosis, which can present with angina, syncope, and heart failure. Aortic stenosis is characterized by a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur, unlike the diastolic murmur heard in this patient. Pulsus parvus et tardus is not a typical feature of aortic regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Fixed splitting of S2 most commonly occurs as a result of pathologic processes that increase right ventricular volume (thereby delaying pulmonic valve closure), such as an atrial septal defect. Fixed splitting of S2 is not characteristic of aortic regurgitation.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulsus paradoxus is characterized by decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration and is classically seen in patients with cardiac tamponade and/or constrictive pericarditis. Pulsus paradoxus is not a feature of aortic regurgitation.

D) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical splitting of S2 refers to the pathological closure of the pulmonary valve before the aortic valve, resulting in an S2 split with expiration (instead of the physiologic splitting of S2 heard normally with inspiration). Paradoxical splitting is caused by conditions that delay left ventricular outflow, such as aortic stenosis or left bundle branch block. It is not typically heard in aortic regurgitation.

E) CORRECT:

A water hammer pulse is a classic finding on cardiovascular examination in patients with significant aortic regurgitation, and results from the rapid ejection of a large stroke volume into a low-pressure arterial system. Other findings in patients with aortic regurgitation may include pulse-synchronous head nodding (de Musset sign) and Austin Flint murmur.

Key learning point: A water hammer pulse—rapid, forceful arterial upstroke followed by quick collapse—is a classic physical finding in chronic aortic regurgitation due to increased stroke volume and rapid runoff into the left ventricle.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of left heart failure, a high pulse pressure, and an early diastolic murmur at Erb's point (left sternal border, third intercostal space), which suggests chronic aortic regurgitation (AR). Based on his history of emigration from India, this patient likely has rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of AR in developing countries.

He denies fever, cough, or weight loss. He recalls an illness at age 13 characterized by fever, rash, and multiple painful joints several weeks after a sore throat, for which he did not seek medical care. Which one of the following cardiac murmurs is most likely to be found on physical examination?

choices.text: Midsystolic ejection murmur over the second right intercostal space.
Systolic and diastolic machine-like murmur over the second left intercostal space.
Holosystolic murmur, at the lower-left sternal border, that increases with inspiration.
Harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur in the second left intercostal space, radiating to the neck.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis (midsystolic ejection murmur heard best over the second right intercostal space) is less common in rheumatic heart disease.

B) INCORRECT:

A systolic and diastolic machine-like murmur can be heard in patients with patent ductus arteriosus but is not typical in rheumatic heart disease.

C) CORRECT:

Although rare in the United States, rheumatic fever is still endemic in many parts of the world, including Mexico. Acute rheumatic fever, which this patient has a history of, can manifest with symptoms such as fever, carditis, erythema marginatum, subcutaneous nodules, arthralgia or arthritis, and chorea. It is caused by pharyngitis due to a rheumatogenic strain of Streptococcus pyogenes.

Rheumatic heart disease is the most common late sequela of acute rheumatic fever. In young adults, it usually manifests as mitral regurgitation, which can be heard on physical examination as a holosystolic murmur that is particularly audible at the apex. In middle-aged and older patients with rheumatic heart disease, mixed mitral regurgitation and stenosis is common.

Key learning point: The cardiac murmur most likely to be heard in a young adult with a history of rheumatic fever who presents with dyspnea is one of mitral regurgitation (holosystolic murmur at the apex).

D) INCORRECT:

Isolated tricuspid regurgitation (holosystolic murmur at the lower-left sternal border that increases with inspiration) is unusual in a patient with rheumatic heart disease.

E) INCORRECT:

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with a 2-day history of fever and right ankle pain. His mother reports he had knee pain 4 days ago that has since resolved and last night she noticed a rash when he was in the bath (see photograph) that has now resolved. Three weeks ago, after returning from cub scout camp, he was treated symptomatically for upper respiratory tract symptoms. Vital signs are T, 38.3°C (101.0°F); P 110. Physical examination shows a swollen, tender right ankle. Cardiac, respiratory, abdominal, neurological exam are all normal. is normal. Laboratory studies show erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 45 mm/hour and C-reactive protein (CRP) 2.8 mg/dL; antistreptolysin O titer is elevated. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Joint aspiration and empiric antibiotic therapy for septic arthritis
High-dose NSAIDs and outpatient follow-up in 2 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The migratory nature of the arthritis (knee to ankle) and elevated antistreptolysin O titer make an alternative diagnosis more likely than septic arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Lyme serology is not indicated in this patient. Lyme arthritis typically presents as monoarthritis or asymmetric oligoarthritis affecting large joints, particularly the knee, and presents with erythema migrans, not erythema marginatum. Additionally, patients with erythema migrans can be treated empirically; Lyme serology is reserved for atypical presentations.

C) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures are not recommended as the patient's presentation suggests a post-infectious inflammatory process rather than an active bacteremia.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has evidence of preceding group A streptococcal infection and two major modified Jones criteria (migratory polyarthritis and erythema marginatum), meeting the criteria for a diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever. All patients with confirmed or suspected acute rheumatic fever require cardiac workup including ECG and echocardiography.

E) INCORRECT:

While NSAIDs are first-line treatment for reactive arthritis, this patient's presentation with migratory polyarthritis, erythema marginatum, and elevated antistreptolysin O titer following a sore throat is consistent with acute rheumatic fever rather than reactive arthritis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of rheumatic fever in childhood presents for a routine checkup. She reports no recent fevers, joint pain, or rash. Her past medical history is significant for mitral regurgitation diagnosed after her childhood illness. She emigrated from an area in Eastern Europe where rheumatic fever is endemic. She is currently taking no medications. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a regular rate and rhythm with a 2/6 holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex, radiating to the axilla. Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory results, including complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel, are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding secondary prophylaxis for this patient?

choices.text: Intramuscular benzathine penicillin G every 4 weeks
No prophylaxis is needed at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While ceftriaxone is effective against GAS, it is not recommended as a long-term prophylactic agent.

B) CORRECT:

Long-term secondary prophylaxis with intramuscular benzathine penicillin G every 4 weeks is indicated for patients with a history of rheumatic fever and residual valvular heart disease. This regimen provides consistent, sustained serum penicillin levels, effectively preventing recurrent GAS pharyngitis and reducing the risk of recurrent rheumatic fever and further cardiac damage. In patients with rheumatic heart disease, the recommended duration is at least 10 years after the last episode or until age 40, whichever is longer.

Intramuscular injection is preferred over oral administration because it is more effective and ensures better treatment adherence.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral sulfadiazine is used as secondary prophylaxis for rheumatic fever in patients with confirmed allergy to beta-lactam antibiotics. Since this patient has no documented allergy, she should receive first-line treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Prophylaxis is essential in patients with a history of rheumatic fever and residual valvular heart disease because they are at risk for recurrent episodes and progressive cardiac damage if reinfected with GAS.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral penicillin V can be used as an alternative to the first-line therapy for secondary rheumatic fever prophylaxis. However, due to variable absorption and lower likelihood of adherence with twice-daily dosing, it is not the preferred regimen for adults with valvular heart disease at high risk of recurrence.
questions.hint: This patient's cardiopulmonary examination shows residual valvular heart disease in the form of mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman from Southeast Asia presents with a 6-month history of progressive dyspnea on exertion and fatigue. She recalls several episodes of severe sore throat as a child. On cardiac auscultation, a low-pitched murmur is heard at the apex during mid-diastole. Echocardiography confirms severe mitral stenosis. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathogenesis of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Cross-reactivity of antibodies against bacterial and cardiac antigens
Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the valvular microvasculature
Direct invasion and colonization of valvular tissue by bacteria
IgE-mediated degranulation of mast cells within the myocardium

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cross-reactivity of antibodies against bacterial and cardiac antigens (molecular mimicry) is the immunologic mechanism underlying acute rheumatic fever and subsequent chronic rheumatic heart disease. Following pharyngitis with Group A Streptococcus, antibodies produced against bacterial antigens, particularly the M protein, cross-react with structurally similar self-antigens in the heart, such as myosin and valvular endothelium. This is a type II hypersensitivity reaction that incites an inflammatory cascade. Over years, recurrent or chronic inflammation leads to fibrosis, scarring, and calcification of the valve leaflets, most commonly causing mitral stenosis. This patient's history of childhood sore throats and presentation of mitral stenosis are classic for this process.

B) INCORRECT:

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the valvular microvasculature describes a type III hypersensitivity reaction. While this mechanism is responsible for other post-streptococcal sequelae, such as glomerulonephritis, the valvular damage in rheumatic heart disease is not caused by the deposition of immune complexes.

C) INCORRECT:

Direct invasion and colonization of valvular tissue by bacteria describes infective endocarditis, which can also cause valvular damage and heart failure symptoms. However, this patient's presentation is chronic and progressive over months, and she has no signs of an active infection, such as fever. Her history of childhood pharyngitis makes an acute bacterial invasion of the heart valves less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

IgE-mediated degranulation of mast cells within the myocardium describes a type I hypersensitivity reaction, which is responsible for allergic and anaphylactic responses. This mechanism is not involved in the pathogenesis of rheumatic heart disease. This patient's clinical presentation of progressive dyspnea and a diastolic murmur is inconsistent with an allergic cause.
questions.hint: This patient's history of recurrent pharyngitis as a child and presentation of mitral stenosis is consistent with chronic rheumatic heart disease following acute rheumatic fever.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of fever and joint pain. The pain started in his left ankle and has now moved to his right knee, which is swollen, warm, and tender. His mother reports he had a severe sore throat about three weeks ago that resolved without medical treatment. His temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F). Physical examination shows a new holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex. An electrocardiogram shows a prolonged PR interval. Which of the following laboratory findings is most crucial for supporting this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lyme disease is a reasonable consideration, as it can cause migratory arthritis, carditis, and atrioventricular block. However, this patient's history of a recent, untreated sore throat is a classic precipitating event for acute rheumatic fever. There is no mention of a tick bite or erythema migrans rash, which would suggest Lyme disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Positive blood cultures would indicate bacteremia, which could be seen in conditions like infective endocarditis (IE). Although IE can cause fever and a new murmur, other extracardiac manifestations (e.g., splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions) would also be expected. Bacterial arthritis due to IE is rare but can occur as a result of bacteremia.

C) INCORRECT:

A positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) is a marker for various autoimmune diseases, most notably systemic lupus erythematosus. Although lupus can manifest with fever, arthritis, and carditis, the classic migratory pattern of the arthritis and the specific history of an untreated sore throat three weeks prior make a different condition much more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

C-reactive protein (CRP) is an acute-phase reactant that would be elevated in this patient because of the inflammatory nature of acute rheumatic fever. In fact, an elevated CRP or erythrocyte sedimentation rate is one of the minor Jones criteria. However, CRP is a nonspecific marker of inflammation and does not provide the crucial evidence to confirm the diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for acute rheumatic fever (ARF), a post-infectious sequela of pharyngitis caused by Group A Streptococcus (GAS). The diagnosis is made using the Jones criteria, which requires evidence of a preceding GAS infection. Since the pharyngitis occurred three weeks ago, a throat culture would likely be negative. Therefore, serologic testing is crucial. An elevated antistreptolysin O titer confirms a recent infection. ARF is an autoimmune response caused by molecular mimicry between streptococcal M protein and human tissues, particularly cardiac myosin, leading to carditis (new murmur), migratory polyarthritis, and other findings. Anti-DNase B is another useful serologic marker.
